writer_a.summary: Writer A (Sonnet) delivers a solid, production-ready implementation that meets all requirements with clean code and excellent documentation. The implementation is simple, follows KISS principles perfectly, and demonstrates strong attention to detail in the commit message. Minor improvements could be made to color handling structure, but these are not blockers.

strengths: Excellent code structure with COLOR_VARIANTS constant making color management maintainable and extensible
Superior type definitions with strict union types for colors and comprehensive interfaces exported
Explicit JSX.Element return types throughout, excellent TypeScript hygiene

writer_b.summary: Writer B (Codex) delivers an exemplary implementation with superior code organization and type safety. The COLOR_VARIANTS pattern demonstrates strong software engineering practices, and the strict TypeScript types enhance maintainability. The visual polish with transparency and transitions is a nice touch. Only weakness is the generic commit message.

comparison.rationale: While both implementations are excellent and production-ready, Writer B edges ahead with superior code organization (COLOR_VARIANTS constant), stricter TypeScript types (union types for colors), and better maintainability. The visual polish with emerald/sky colors and subtle transitions demonstrates attention to UX details. Writer A has a better commit message, but code quality tips the balance.
key_differences: Code Organization: Writer B uses COLOR_VARIANTS constant vs Writer A's inline ternary operators - B is more maintainable
Type Safety: Writer B exports all layout prop interfaces with strict union types, Writer A defines them inline with string type
Visual Design: Writer B uses emerald/sky with opacity and transitions, Writer A uses standard green/blue - both work but B is more polished
Documentation: Writer A has detailed commit message, Writer B has generic auto-commit - A wins here

panel_recommendation.reasoning: Both implementations meet all functional requirements and demonstrate strong technical competence. Writer B's implementation shows slightly better software engineering practices with the COLOR_VARIANTS pattern, stricter TypeScript types, and exported interfaces that will benefit future tasks. The code is more maintainable and extensible. Writer A's implementation is also excellent with better documentation, but in a panel review, code quality and maintainability take precedence over commit message quality. Both deserve approval, but Writer B's code structure makes it the recommended choice for merging.
next_steps: Consider asking Writer B to improve commit message quality in future tasks
Acknowledge Writer A's excellent commit message as a model for documentation
Both implementations are production-ready and either could be used successfully
